parts: How do I change which email notifications I receive? I'm getting too many alerts.

Go to Settings > Notifications > Email Preferences. You can toggle each notification type independently: order confirmations, shipping updates, inventory alerts, weekly summaries, and system announcements. You can also set a 'quiet hours' schedule where only critical alerts are delivered.
Can I set different notification preferences for different team members?

Yes, each user manages their own notification preferences. As an admin, you can also set organization-level defaults under Admin > Notifications > Default Preferences. Individual users can then override these defaults for their own accounts.
We need your PCI DSS compliance documentation for our annual audit. Where can we find your Attestation of Compliance and SAQ?

You can access our PCI compliance documentation in the Trust Center at trust.example.com/compliance. We're PCI DSS Level 1 certified. Available documents include: Attestation of Compliance (AoC), our latest SAQ-D, penetration test summary, and our responsibility matrix showing which PCI requirements we handle vs. what falls on the merchant.
Our auditor also wants to know about your encryption standards for stored card data.

We use AES-256 encryption for card data at rest, with keys managed through an HSM (Hardware Security Module). Card numbers are tokenized at the point of entry — we never store raw PANs. All data in transit uses TLS 1.3. The detailed encryption architecture document is available under NDA — I'll have our compliance team send it directly to your auditor.
We're migrating from WooCommerce. What data can be transferred and what do we lose?

Our WooCommerce migration transfers: products (with variants, images, categories), customers (with addresses and order history), orders (with line items, notes, and status), coupons, blog posts, and pages. What doesn't transfer: custom plugin data, theme customizations, and WooCommerce-specific shortcodes in content. The migration preserves URL slugs for SEO continuity.
How long will the migration take? We have about 2,000 products and 50,000 orders.

For that volume, expect 4-6 hours for the full migration. Products go first (about 30 minutes), then customers (1 hour), then orders (3-4 hours since it's the bulk of the data). We do the migration in the background — your WooCommerce store stays live during the process. Once migration is verified, you switch DNS to point to us. We recommend doing a test migration first to verify everything looks correct before the final cutover.
We need to set up sales tax collection for all US states where we have nexus. We currently have nexus in CA, NY, TX, and FL.

Go to Settings > Taxes > US Sales Tax. We integrate with TaxJar for automatic rate calculation. Enable tax collection for your nexus states, and our system will automatically apply the correct rate based on the customer's shipping address — including state, county, and city taxes. TaxJar stays updated with rate changes automatically.
What about states with marketplace facilitator laws? We sell on Amazon too.

Great question. For marketplace sales (Amazon, eBay, etc.), the marketplace collects and remits tax in most states under facilitator laws. In your tax settings, mark those states as 'Marketplace Collected' so you don't double-collect. Your direct website sales still need you to collect. We can generate state-by-state tax reports that separate marketplace vs. direct for filing purposes.
I need to reset my admin portal password. I tried the forgot password link but didn't receive the email.
I can help with that. Let me verify your identity first. What email address is associated with your admin account?
alice@techcorp.com

I've sent a password reset link to alice@techcorp.com. Please check your spam folder as well. The link expires in 30 minutes. If you still don't receive it, we may need to verify your email configuration.
We want to set up an automated fulfillment workflow. When an order is paid, we need it to automatically route to the correct warehouse based on the customer's location.

You can set this up with our Fulfillment Rules engine. Go to Orders > Fulfillment > Rules. Create rules based on: shipping country, shipping state/province, product category, or order weight. Each rule maps to a fulfillment location. For example: 'If shipping_country = US AND shipping_state IN (CA, OR, WA) THEN route to West Coast warehouse'.
What happens if a rule conflicts — like an order matching two rules?

Rules are evaluated in priority order (drag to reorder). The first matching rule wins. We also have a 'fallback' location that catches any orders that don't match any rule. I'd recommend setting your highest-volume warehouse as the fallback to handle edge cases gracefully.
We need to set up inventory sync between our warehouse management system and your platform. What integration options do you support?

We support three inventory sync methods: 1) Real-time webhooks — your WMS pushes updates as they happen, 2) Scheduled batch sync — CSV/SFTP upload on a schedule, 3) Direct API integration — our system pulls from your WMS API. For most warehouses, real-time webhooks provide the best experience. Which WMS are you using?
We use ShipStation for our WMS.

Great news — we have a native ShipStation integration. Go to Integrations > Warehouse > ShipStation, enter your ShipStation API key, and select which inventory locations to sync. It uses real-time webhooks by default and typically syncs within 30 seconds of a change in ShipStation.
We're receiving webhooks from your platform but want to make sure they're authentic. How do we verify webhook signatures?

Every webhook we send includes an X-Signature header containing an HMAC-SHA256 signature. Your signing secret is in Developer > Webhooks > Signing Secret. To verify: 1) Get the raw request body, 2) Compute HMAC-SHA256(signing_secret, raw_body), 3) Compare with the X-Signature header value. If they match, the webhook is authentic. We have code examples in Python, Node, Ruby, and PHP in our docs.
What if the signing secret is compromised?

You can rotate the signing secret at any time in Developer > Webhooks > Rotate Secret. The new secret takes effect immediately for new webhooks. We recommend: 1) Rotating secrets quarterly, 2) Using a secrets manager (not hardcoded), 3) Accepting both old and new secrets for a 24-hour overlap during rotation. After rotation, the old secret is permanently invalidated.
We need to set up shipping label printing. We currently print labels manually from each carrier's website. Very slow.

Our integrated label printing is much faster. Go to Shipping > Label Printing > Setup. We support: USPS, FedEx, UPS, and DHL. Enter your carrier account numbers (or use our discounted rates). Then from any order, click 'Print Label' — it generates the label, purchases postage, and captures the tracking number automatically. Bulk print up to 100 labels at once.
What kind of printer do we need?

For shipping labels, you have two options: 1) Thermal printer (recommended) — Zebra ZD420 or DYMO 4XL. Prints 4x6 labels directly. No ink, no waste. 2) Laser/inkjet — prints on 8.5x11 paper with cut lines. Works but slower and wasteful. Thermal printers pay for themselves quickly in ink savings. We have plug-and-play drivers for both Zebra and DYMO.
We have a GDPR data subject access request. How do we export all data associated with a specific user from your platform?

For GDPR DSARs, we have a dedicated data export tool. Go to Admin > Compliance > Data Subject Requests. Enter the user's email address and it will compile all data across our systems — account info, activity logs, stored files, and communication records. The export takes about 2 hours for typical accounts and is delivered as an encrypted ZIP file.
Does the export include data from third-party integrations?

The export covers all data stored on our platform, including data received from integrations. However, data that only resides in the third-party system (not synced to us) would need to be requested from that provider separately. Our export includes a manifest listing all connected integrations so you know which providers to contact.
We're building a new integration with your payment API. Is there a sandbox environment we can use for testing?

Yes! Our sandbox mirrors the production API 1:1 with test credentials. Go to Developer > Sandbox to get your test API keys. The sandbox supports: test card numbers (4242424242424242 for success, 4000000000000002 for decline), simulated webhooks, and time manipulation for testing subscription cycles.
Can we simulate specific error scenarios?

Absolutely. Use specific test amounts to trigger errors: $10.01 triggers insufficient funds, $10.02 triggers card expired, $10.03 triggers processing error. You can also use the sandbox API endpoint POST /sandbox/simulate to trigger specific webhook events, chargebacks, and settlement delays on demand.
How do I customize the transactional emails sent to customers? The default templates are too generic for our brand.

Go to Settings > Notifications > Email Templates. You can customize: order confirmation, shipping notification, delivery confirmation, refund notification, account welcome, and password reset. Each template has a visual editor where you can change colors, add your logo, modify copy, and add/remove sections. You can also edit the raw HTML if you need full control.
Can we add dynamic content like product recommendations?

Yes! In the template editor, add a 'Product Recommendations' block. Options: 'Frequently bought together' (based on the ordered items), 'Best sellers', or 'New arrivals'. The recommendations are generated dynamically for each email. This is particularly effective in shipping confirmation emails — customers are engaged and likely to browse while waiting for their order.
Our security team needs an audit of all user permissions in our account. Is there a way to export this?

Yes, go to Admin > Users > Export Permissions. This generates a CSV with every user, their role, and granular permissions. You can also use our API endpoint GET /admin/permissions/audit which returns the same data in JSON format with additional metadata like last login date and permission change history.
Does it include permissions inherited from groups?

The export includes both direct and inherited permissions, clearly marked. Each row shows: user, direct_role, group_memberships, effective_permissions (the combined set), and the source of each permission (direct or which group). This makes it easy for your security team to identify over-privileged accounts.
We want to create product bundles where buying items together is cheaper than individually. How do we set this up?

Go to Products > Bundles > Create. You can build: 1) Fixed bundles (predefined set of products at a bundle price), 2) Mix-and-match bundles (customer picks 3 items from a collection, gets 20% off), 3) BOGO bundles (buy one, get one free/discounted). Each bundle has its own product page and inventory tracking. Bundle inventory is automatically deducted from individual product stock.
What happens if one item in a bundle goes out of stock?

By default, the bundle becomes unavailable when any component is out of stock. You can change this behavior per bundle: 1) 'All required' — bundle unavailable if any component is out, 2) 'Substitution' — suggest an alternative product, 3) 'Partial' — sell the bundle with the available items at adjusted price. Most merchants use 'All required' for fixed bundles and 'Partial' for mix-and-match.
I want to create a custom analytics dashboard showing our key metrics. What widgets are available?

Go to Analytics > Dashboards > Create. Available widgets: Revenue (daily/weekly/monthly), Orders (count, AOV, trends), Top products, Traffic sources, Conversion funnel, Customer lifetime value, Inventory turnover, Return rate, Geographic heatmap, and Custom SQL queries. Drag and drop widgets to arrange. Each widget has configurable time ranges and comparison periods.
Can I share the dashboard with my team?

Yes, dashboards can be shared. Click the share icon on your dashboard and choose: 1) Team members (they get full interactive access), 2) Scheduled email (sends a PDF snapshot weekly/monthly), 3) Public link (view-only, great for investors or partners — no login required, but no filtering). Most teams create 2-3 dashboards: executive summary, marketing performance, and operations.
What are the current API rate limits for our enterprise plan? We're planning a data migration and need to know how many requests per second we can make.

On the Enterprise plan, your rate limits are: 1,000 requests/second for read endpoints, 200 requests/second for write endpoints, and 50 requests/second for bulk operations. For data migrations, I'd recommend using the bulk import endpoint which has a separate limit of 10,000 records per batch.
Perfect, the bulk import endpoint sounds right. Is there documentation on the batch format?

Yes! You can find the bulk import documentation at docs.example.com/api/bulk-import. The format is NDJSON (newline-delimited JSON), and each batch can contain up to 10,000 records. I'd also recommend using our migration SDK which handles batching, retries, and progress tracking automatically.
We have 3 retail locations plus an online warehouse. How do we manage inventory across all locations?

Our multi-location inventory system lets you track stock per location. Go to Inventory > Locations and add each location. Each location gets its own inventory counts, and the platform automatically aggregates totals for your online store. You can configure: which locations fulfill online orders, transfer stock between locations, and set location-specific pricing if needed.
How does online order routing work when multiple locations have stock?

Online orders are routed based on your fulfillment rules. Default behavior is 'nearest to customer' using the shipping address zip code. You can override with: 1) Priority-based (always try Location A first), 2) Round-robin (distribute evenly), 3) Capacity-based (route to location with most stock). Set this in Orders > Fulfillment > Multi-Location Strategy.
We need to import our product catalog — about 5,000 SKUs. What's the best way to do this?

For 5,000 SKUs, use our bulk import tool. Go to Products > Import > Bulk Upload. The CSV format requires: sku, name, description, price, weight, category, inventory_quantity, and image_url. You can import up to 10,000 products per batch. I'd recommend splitting into batches of 2,500 for easier error handling.
What about product variants like size and color?

Variants are handled by adding variant columns to the CSV: variant_option_1_name, variant_option_1_value, variant_option_2_name, variant_option_2_value, variant_price (if different from base), and variant_sku. A product with 3 sizes and 2 colors would be 6 rows in the CSV, all sharing the same base SKU but with unique variant_sku values.
We process about 200 orders a day. How can we streamline batch processing?

Our Batch Processing tools handle high-volume workflows. Go to Orders > Batch Actions. Key features: 1) Bulk print labels (select all, print in one batch), 2) Bulk status update (mark multiple orders as shipped), 3) Batch pick list generation (consolidated picking list organized by warehouse zone), 4) Scan-to-ship (scan order barcode → auto-print label → mark shipped). Most 200+/day merchants use the scan-to-ship workflow.
How does the pick list work?

Go to Orders > Fulfillment > Generate Pick List. It takes all unfulfilled orders and creates an optimized picking route organized by warehouse zone/aisle. Each item shows: SKU, product name, quantity, bin location, and which orders it's for. You can print the pick list or display it on a tablet. After picking, scan each item to verify — the system flags any mismatches before you pack. This reduces picking errors by about 95%.
We're reorganizing our warehouse and want to set up bin locations in your system. How does this work?

Go to Inventory > Warehouse > Bin Locations. You can create a hierarchical structure: Zone > Aisle > Shelf > Bin. For example: Zone A > Aisle 3 > Shelf 2 > Bin 15 becomes 'A-3-2-15'. Assign products to bin locations, and pick lists will include the bin location for each item. You can assign multiple products to one bin and one product to multiple bins (for popular items stored in multiple locations).
Can we import our existing bin structure?

Yes — use Inventory > Warehouse > Import Bin Map. The CSV format is: zone, aisle, shelf, bin, sku, quantity. This lets you set up your entire warehouse map in one import. After import, verify with Inventory > Warehouse > Map View which shows a visual representation of your warehouse with fill levels per zone. This helps identify optimization opportunities like moving fast-movers closer to the packing station.
Our webhooks have been failing intermittently for the past week. We're getting about a 30% failure rate according to your dashboard.
Let me check your webhook delivery logs. What's your webhook endpoint URL and which events are configured?
Endpoint is https://api.bobcorp.com/webhooks/ingest and we're subscribed to order.created, order.updated, and payment.completed events.

I can see the issue. Your endpoint is returning 502 errors during peak hours (2-4 PM UTC). Our system retries 3 times with exponential backoff, but during sustained 502 periods, deliveries are eventually dropped. I'd recommend: 1) Check your endpoint's scaling — it may need more capacity, 2) Enable our webhook queue feature which buffers deliveries for up to 24 hours, 3) Use our replay endpoint to re-deliver any missed webhooks from the past 7 days.
We want to point our custom domain to the store. How do we set this up?

Go to Settings > Domains > Add Custom Domain. Enter your domain (e.g., shop.yourcompany.com). We'll provide DNS records to add at your registrar: a CNAME record pointing to our CDN. Once DNS propagates (usually 15-30 minutes), we automatically provision an SSL certificate via Let's Encrypt. Your store will be accessible at your custom domain with full HTTPS.
Can we use an apex domain (without www) or does it have to be a subdomain?

Both work! For apex domains (yourcompany.com), you'll need to set up A records instead of CNAME. We provide 4 IP addresses for redundancy. The SSL certificate covers both the apex domain and www subdomain. We automatically redirect www to non-www (or vice versa, your choice). Most merchants use the apex domain for a cleaner URL.
We're upgrading from API v2 to v3 and the authentication changed. Can you explain the new OAuth2 flow?

API v3 uses OAuth2 with client credentials grant for server-to-server communication. The flow: 1) Register your app in Developer > Apps > Create to get a client_id and client_secret, 2) POST to /oauth/token with grant_type=client_credentials, 3) Receive an access token (valid 1 hour), 4) Include token as 'Authorization: Bearer {token}' in all API requests. Tokens auto-refresh if you use our SDK.
What about webhooks? Do they still use the signing secret?

Yes, webhook verification hasn't changed. Webhooks still use HMAC-SHA256 signing with your signing secret. The OAuth2 change only affects outbound API calls from your server to our API. This separation is intentional — webhooks need stateless verification without token management. Your existing webhook verification code should work unchanged.
We want to implement saved payment methods for returning customers. How does your tokenization work?

Our tokenization creates a secure token that represents a customer's payment method. The flow is: 1) Customer enters card details in our hosted payment field (PCI scope stays with us), 2) We return a token (tok_xxxx), 3) You store the token in your database, 4) For future charges, send the token instead of card details. Tokens are merchant-specific and can't be used across different merchants.
How long do tokens remain valid?

Tokens remain valid as long as the underlying card is valid. When a card expires, the token becomes invalid. However, we participate in card account updater programs with Visa and Mastercard — if a card is reissued with a new number or expiry, we automatically update the token so it continues to work. This significantly reduces involuntary churn for subscription businesses.
A customer is asking if they can save multiple payment methods. How does that work on our store?

Customers can save multiple payment methods in their account. Under My Account > Payment Methods, they can add cards, PayPal, and bank accounts. They can set a default payment method and switch at checkout. All saved methods are tokenized — we never store raw card data. Customers can delete saved methods at any time.
Is there a limit on saved payment methods?

No hard limit, but we recommend setting a reasonable cap under Settings > Customers > Payment Methods > Max Saved (default is 10). Most customers save 2-3 methods. Expired cards are automatically flagged and the customer is prompted to update them at their next checkout.
We noticed you released API v3. What's your deprecation timeline for v2? We have a lot of integrations built on v2.

Our API versioning policy gives 18 months of overlap between major versions. API v2 will be fully supported until June 2026, with security-only patches until December 2026. After that, v2 endpoints will return 410 Gone responses. We recommend starting migration to v3 now — the main breaking changes are in the authentication flow and pagination format.
What's the easiest migration path? We can't rewrite everything at once.

Use our v2-to-v3 compatibility shim. Add the header `X-API-Compat: v2` to your v3 requests and the response format will match v2 structure. This lets you point at v3 endpoints immediately while migrating response handling gradually. The only thing you must change immediately is authentication — v3 uses OAuth2 instead of API keys.
How do I set up low stock alerts so we don't oversell? We've had a few incidents where products sold out but we kept taking orders.

Go to Inventory > Alerts > Low Stock Thresholds. You can set thresholds per product or per category. When stock hits the threshold, you'll get an email/Slack notification. To prevent overselling, also enable 'Out of Stock Protection' under Inventory > Settings — this automatically hides products when inventory reaches zero.
Can we set different thresholds for fast-moving vs slow-moving products?

Yes, you can set thresholds at three levels: 1) Global default (applies to all products), 2) Category level (e.g., 'Electronics' gets threshold of 50), 3) Individual product level (your best-seller might need a threshold of 200). More specific rules override less specific ones. We also have a 'Smart Threshold' beta feature that automatically adjusts thresholds based on sales velocity.
Our SEO agency is asking about our sitemap configuration. Is the sitemap generated automatically?

Yes, we auto-generate XML sitemaps at yourstore.com/sitemap.xml. It includes: all published products, collections/categories, blog posts, and static pages. The sitemap updates automatically when you add or remove content. It's also automatically submitted to Google Search Console if you've connected your account under Settings > SEO > Search Console.
Can we exclude certain pages from the sitemap?

Yes — on any page or product, go to SEO settings and toggle 'Exclude from sitemap'. This also sets the page as 'noindex'. Common exclusions: thank-you pages, internal landing pages, and test products. For bulk exclusions, add URL patterns under Settings > SEO > Sitemap Exclusions (e.g., /internal/* to exclude all URLs starting with /internal/).
We need to add custom fields to our checkout — specifically a 'Purchase Order Number' field for B2B customers.

Go to Settings > Checkout > Custom Fields. You can add fields with types: text, dropdown, checkbox, and date. For your PO Number, add a text field with label 'Purchase Order Number', make it optional (so B2C customers can skip it), and set it to appear in the order confirmation email and packing slip. The value is stored in the order's metadata and accessible via API.
Can we make it required only for certain customer groups?

Yes — use conditional visibility. In the custom field settings, add a condition: 'Show only when customer group = Wholesale'. You can also make it required only for that group. B2C customers won't see the field at all. This keeps the checkout clean for regular customers while collecting the data B2B customers need. The field data is also included in order exports and webhook payloads.
Hi, I'm experiencing a billing discrepancy in BillingEngine. I'm getting error code ERR-4401 when trying to reconcile our November invoices. The total charges don't match what was quoted.

I'm sorry to hear about the billing discrepancy in BillingEngine. Error ERR-4401 typically indicates a mismatch between the invoice line items and the billing ledger totals. Let me look into your account. Can you provide your account ID and the specific invoice numbers affected?
Account ID is ALICE-7291. The invoices are INV-2025-1101 through INV-2025-1115. The discrepancy is about $2,340 — our ledger shows charges that don't appear on the invoices.

Thank you, Alice. I've pulled up your account ALICE-7291. I can see the ERR-4401 error was triggered during the reconciliation batch job on November 17th. It appears that 12 line items from your subscription tier adjustment on November 3rd were not properly propagated to the invoice generation module. This is a known issue we're tracking internally. I'm escalating this to our billing engineering team and we'll issue corrected invoices within 48 hours.
That's helpful. Is there a workaround in the meantime so our finance team can close the books?

Yes — you can use the manual reconciliation override in BillingEngine under Settings > Reconciliation > Force Sync. Enter the correct totals manually and reference ticket BILL-4401-ALICE. This will allow your finance team to proceed while we fix the underlying ERR-4401 issue on our side.
We're launching in Europe and need to accept EUR and GBP in addition to USD. How do we enable multi-currency?

Multi-currency is available on the Business and Enterprise plans. Go to PaymentGateway > Settings > Currencies and enable the currencies you need. You'll also need to: 1) Set up a multi-currency bank account or use our managed payouts feature, 2) Configure exchange rate preferences (real-time market rate or locked daily rate), 3) Update your checkout to pass the currency code with each transaction.
What about conversion fees?

Currency conversion is 1.5% above the mid-market rate for real-time conversion. If you use locked daily rates, it's 2.0% but gives you predictable pricing for the day. We recommend real-time rates for most merchants. Settlement is always in your base currency unless you opt for multi-currency settlement (requires separate bank accounts per currency).
We want to offer shipping insurance to customers. Do you integrate with any insurance providers?

We integrate with Route and Shipsurance for shipping insurance. Go to Integrations > Shipping > Insurance. Once connected, an optional insurance checkbox appears at checkout. The customer pays a small premium (typically 1-2% of order value) and gets full coverage for lost, stolen, or damaged packages. Claims are handled directly by the insurance provider — no work for your team.
Who pays for the insurance — us or the customer?

By default, the customer pays the premium as an add-on at checkout. But you can configure it under Settings > Shipping > Insurance: 1) Customer-paid (default — customer sees and opts in), 2) Merchant-paid (you absorb the cost — great for premium brands), 3) Included above a threshold (free insurance on orders over $100). About 25-30% of customers opt in when it's customer-paid. Merchant-paid can reduce support costs since all claims go through the provider.
We're losing a lot of potential sales to abandoned carts. Do you have a recovery tool?

Yes, our abandoned cart recovery is built-in. Go to Marketing > Abandoned Carts > Enable Recovery. The default sequence sends 3 emails: 1) 1 hour after abandonment — a reminder, 2) 24 hours — add a 5% discount code, 3) 72 hours — last chance with 10% discount. You can customize timing, messaging, and discount amounts. Average recovery rate is 8-12%.
Can we also retarget with ads?

Yes, abandoned cart data automatically syncs to Facebook and Google Ads audiences (if connected). Go to Integrations > Ads > Audience Sync and enable 'Cart Abandoners' audience. This creates a dynamic audience of users who abandoned in the last 7 days (configurable). Combined with email recovery, most merchants see a 15-20% total recovery rate.

We're seeing billing discrepancies in BillingEngine. Error ERR-4401 is showing up when our accounting team tries to reconcile invoices for November. The charged amounts don't line up with the quoted prices.

I understand you're experiencing billing discrepancies in BillingEngine with error ERR-4401. This error relates to mismatches between invoice line items and the billing ledger. Could you share your account ID and which invoices are affected?
Sure, account BOB-3382. Invoices INV-2025-1108 through INV-2025-1120. We're seeing a discrepancy of roughly $1,870 — charges on the ledger that aren't reflected in the invoices.

Thank you, Bob. Looking at account BOB-3382, I can confirm the ERR-4401 error was triggered during your reconciliation on November 18th. Similar to other reports we've received, subscription tier changes from early November didn't propagate correctly to invoice generation. Our billing engineering team is actively working on a fix. We'll have corrected invoices for you within 48 hours.
Is there anything we can do on our end while waiting for the fix? Our CFO is asking for the numbers.

Absolutely — in BillingEngine, go to Settings > Reconciliation > Force Sync. You can manually enter the correct totals and reference ticket BILL-4401-BOB. This workaround lets your finance team close out while we resolve the ERR-4401 issue systemically.
We're trying to set up SSO with Okta but getting SAML assertion errors. The error message says 'Invalid audience restriction'.

The 'Invalid audience restriction' error means the Entity ID in your Okta app doesn't match what our platform expects. In Okta, the Audience URI should be set to: https://auth.example.com/saml/sp/YOUR_ORG_ID. You can find your ORG_ID in Admin > Settings > Organization.
Found it and updated. Now I'm getting 'Signature validation failed'.

That's the next common issue. You need to upload your Okta signing certificate to our platform. In Admin > Security > SSO Configuration, click 'Upload IdP Certificate' and paste the X.509 certificate from your Okta app's 'Sign On' tab. Make sure to copy the full certificate including the BEGIN/END markers.
We're launching a monthly subscription box. Each month we curate different products. How do we manage this?

Use our Subscription product type with curated fulfillment. Create a subscription product (Products > Create > Type: Subscription) with monthly billing. For the curation aspect, use our 'Subscription Box Manager' under Products > Subscriptions > Manage Boxes. Each month, you assign products to that month's box. The system handles: recurring billing, shipment scheduling, and inventory reservation for box contents.
Can subscribers customize their box or is it fully curated?

Both models are supported. Under Subscription Box Manager, choose: 1) 'Fully Curated' — you pick everything, 2) 'Partial Choice' — you pick 3 items, subscriber chooses 2 from a selection, 3) 'Build Your Own' — subscriber selects all items from a catalog. For partial choice and build-your-own, subscribers receive an email 5 days before billing asking them to make selections. If they don't select, a default box is shipped.
We're building a mobile app and want to send push notifications for order updates. How do we integrate?

We support push notifications through our Webhooks + your push provider setup. The flow is: 1) Configure webhooks for order events (order.shipped, order.delivered, etc.), 2) Your server receives the webhook, 3) Your server sends a push notification via Firebase (Android) or APNs (iOS). We don't have a direct push integration but our webhook payload contains all the data you need.
Any plans to support direct push notifications?

It's on our roadmap for Q2 2026. In the meantime, our webhook approach gives you full control over push content and timing. Many of our larger merchants prefer this approach anyway since they can customize the push notification copy and add deep links specific to their app.
Our return label generation is failing. Customers click 'Generate Return Label' and get a blank page.

This sounds like it could be a browser compatibility or API key issue. Can you check: 1) Does it happen in all browsers? 2) Is your return shipping API key still valid in Settings > Returns > Carrier Keys? 3) Are you using our latest return portal version?
It's happening in all browsers. The API key shows as 'Active' and we're on version 2.3.

Version 2.3 has a known issue with return label generation when the return address has special characters. Please update to version 2.4 which includes the fix. Go to Settings > Returns > Portal Version and click 'Update'. The update takes about 5 minutes to propagate.
We want to give our suppliers access to see their product inventory levels and incoming POs. Is there a supplier portal?

We have a Supplier Portal feature on the Enterprise plan. Go to Admin > Suppliers > Enable Portal. Each supplier gets login credentials and can view: their products' inventory levels, open purchase orders, receiving history, and lead time performance metrics. They can also update estimated delivery dates on open POs, which automatically updates your expected restock dates.
Can suppliers submit invoices through the portal?

Yes, suppliers can upload invoices against specific POs. The invoices appear in your Admin > Suppliers > Invoices queue for approval. You can enable 3-way matching (PO amount, receiving qty, invoice amount) to auto-approve matching invoices. Discrepancies are flagged for manual review. This eliminates a lot of email back-and-forth with suppliers.
We use Square for our in-store POS. Can we sync inventory between Square and your platform?

Yes, we have a native Square POS integration. Go to Integrations > POS > Square. Connect your Square account and map your locations. The integration syncs: inventory counts (bi-directional, near real-time), product catalog (your platform is the source of truth), and sales data (Square sales reduce your online inventory). Initial sync takes about an hour for most catalogs.
What happens if there's a sync conflict — like a product sells online and in-store simultaneously?

We handle this with optimistic concurrency and a 'last write wins' policy with conflict logging. Both sales go through (preventing customer-facing errors), and if the combined sales exceed inventory, you'll get an oversell alert within 5 minutes. You can also set a 'safety buffer' — reserving a portion of inventory for each channel to prevent overselling during sync delays.
Our analytics dashboard has been loading really slowly the past few days. Takes about 30 seconds to render.

I'm sorry about the slow dashboard experience. A few things to check: 1) What date range are you querying? Large ranges can slow rendering. 2) How many widgets do you have active? 3) Are you using any custom SQL widgets?
Date range is last 90 days, about 12 widgets, and yes we have 3 custom SQL widgets.

The 3 custom SQL widgets with a 90-day range are likely the bottleneck. Custom SQL widgets don't use our pre-aggregated data and run against raw tables. I'd recommend: 1) Reduce the date range to 30 days for custom widgets, 2) Add indexes on the columns your custom queries filter by, or 3) Contact our data team to add your custom metrics to the pre-aggregation pipeline for faster queries.
We want to send post-purchase surveys to measure customer satisfaction. Do you have a survey tool?

We have a built-in NPS/CSAT survey tool. Go to Marketing > Surveys > Create. Choose: NPS (0-10 scale), CSAT (1-5 stars), or custom questions. Configure delivery timing (e.g., 7 days after delivery), and the survey is sent via email. Results are aggregated in a dashboard showing trends, response rate, and free-text feedback. Most merchants send CSAT surveys 7 days post-delivery for the best response rates.
Can we trigger different follow-ups based on the score?

Yes — create conditional flows. For example: score 1-3 → auto-create a support ticket for follow-up. Score 4-5 → send a 'Thank you! Leave us a review?' email with a link to your review page. Score 8-10 (NPS) → ask for a referral with a referral code. This turns feedback into action automatically and helps recover unhappy customers before they churn or leave negative public reviews.
We want to launch a points-based loyalty program. Do you support this natively?

We have a built-in loyalty program module. Go to Marketing > Loyalty > Enable. Configure: points per dollar spent, redemption rate (e.g., 100 points = $1), bonus point events (birthday, referral, first purchase), tier levels (Bronze, Silver, Gold with increasing multipliers), and point expiration policy. Customers see their points balance on their account page and at checkout.
What about VIP tiers with exclusive perks?

Tiers are fully customizable. For each tier, set: point threshold to qualify, point multiplier (e.g., Gold gets 2x points), exclusive discounts (auto-applied at checkout), early access to sales (time-gated product visibility), and free shipping thresholds. Customers see their tier progress and what they need to reach the next level. The gamification aspect drives significant repeat purchase behavior.
How do we customize the storefront theme beyond the basic settings? We need to match our brand identity exactly.

You have three levels of customization: 1) Theme Editor (Settings > Theme > Customize) — visual editor for colors, fonts, layout, and sections. No coding required. 2) CSS Override (Theme > Advanced > Custom CSS) — add custom CSS rules that override the theme. 3) Theme Code Editor (Theme > Advanced > Edit Code) — full access to Liquid templates, HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. For brand-exact customization, most merchants use a combination of levels 1 and 2.
Can we preview changes before publishing them live?

Yes, all theme changes are made in a preview mode first. You see a live preview as you make changes, and nothing goes live until you click 'Publish'. You can also create theme drafts (Theme > Drafts > Create) to work on major redesigns without affecting the live store. When ready, swap drafts instantly. We keep version history of the last 20 published versions, so you can roll back if needed.
We want to automate our return process. Currently it's all manual — customer emails us, we create a return, send a label, etc.

Our self-service returns portal handles this end-to-end. Go to Orders > Returns > Portal Setup. Customers can: 1) Select the order and items to return, 2) Choose a reason (you define the options), 3) Receive a prepaid return label instantly, 4) Track return status. You review returns in your admin and issue refunds when items are received and inspected.
Can we auto-approve returns under certain conditions?

Yes — set up auto-approval rules under Returns > Rules. Common rules: auto-approve if order is within 30 days, auto-approve if item value under $50, auto-approve for loyal customers (5+ orders). For auto-approved returns, the refund is issued immediately when the carrier scans the return package. This saves your team significant time on low-risk returns.
We're getting a lot of returned shipments due to bad addresses. Is there address validation at checkout?

Yes, enable address validation under Settings > Checkout > Address Validation. We use SmartyStreets for real-time USPS, FedEx, and UPS address verification. When a customer enters an address, we validate it and suggest corrections before they complete checkout. This catches: misspelled streets, missing apartment numbers, incorrect zip codes, and undeliverable addresses.
What if the customer insists on using an unvalidated address?

You can configure the behavior: 1) 'Strict' — block checkout if address can't be validated, 2) 'Warning' — show a warning but allow checkout, 3) 'Suggestion' — show the validated address as a suggestion, customer chooses. Most merchants use 'Warning' mode. Unvalidated orders get a flag in your admin so your team can verify before shipping. This typically reduces return-to-sender rates by 60-70%.
We dropship some products from suppliers. How do we set up automatic routing so dropship orders go to the supplier?

Use our Dropship Routing feature. Go to Orders > Fulfillment > Dropship > Add Supplier. For each supplier: add their email, set which products/brands they fulfill, and configure the notification format (email with packing slip, EDI, or API). When an order contains dropship items, the system automatically splits it and sends the supplier portion to the appropriate supplier.
What if an order has both dropship and warehouse items?

The system handles split orders automatically. The warehouse portion goes to your fulfillment queue normally, and the dropship portion is sent to the supplier. Both get separate tracking numbers that are combined on the customer's order page. The customer sees one order with multiple shipments. You can configure whether to charge one shipping fee or per-shipment fees under Shipping > Split Order Rules.
What's the CSV format for bulk order imports? We need to upload about 500 orders from our legacy system.

The bulk order import CSV requires these columns: order_id, customer_email, customer_name, shipping_address_line1, shipping_address_city, shipping_address_state, shipping_address_zip, shipping_address_country, item_sku, item_quantity, item_price. I'll email you a template with sample data. Maximum 1,000 orders per batch.
Do you support multiple items per order in the CSV?

Yes — use one row per line item with the same order_id. Our importer groups rows by order_id automatically. So a 3-item order would be 3 rows in the CSV, all sharing the same order_id but with different item_sku, item_quantity, and item_price values.
Our checkout abandonment rate is 72%. What can we do to improve it?

72% is actually close to the industry average (70%), but there's room to improve. Key optimizations: 1) Enable guest checkout (don't force account creation), 2) Reduce form fields — use address autocomplete, 3) Show all costs upfront (no surprise shipping at checkout), 4) Add trust badges and security seals, 5) Offer multiple payment methods (Apple Pay, Google Pay reduce friction by 15-20%). Check Settings > Checkout > Optimization for a checklist.
We require account creation. Is guest checkout really that important?

Yes — forced account creation is the #1 reason for checkout abandonment after unexpected costs. Studies show 34% of shoppers abandon when forced to create an account. Our recommendation: offer guest checkout but prompt for optional account creation AFTER purchase ('Save your info for faster checkout next time?'). Conversion rate typically improves 10-15% with this approach, and about 40% of guest customers still create accounts post-purchase.
We have 3 years of order data and the admin is getting sluggish. Can we archive old orders?

Go to Admin > Data Management > Archive. You can archive orders older than a specified date. Archived orders: are removed from the main orders list (improving performance), remain searchable via Admin > Archives, are preserved for reporting and compliance, and can be unarchived individually if needed. Most merchants archive orders older than 12-18 months.
Does archiving affect our analytics and reports?

No — archived orders are still included in all analytics and reports. Only the main orders list in the admin is affected. The analytics engine queries both active and archived data seamlessly. For data retention compliance (GDPR right to erasure), we have a separate 'Delete' function that permanently removes customer data. Archive and delete are completely separate operations.
Our accounting team needs detailed settlement reports for reconciliation. What reporting options do you offer?

We offer several settlement report formats: 1) Daily settlement summary — available in PaymentGateway > Reports, 2) Detailed transaction-level export (CSV) — every transaction with fees, net amount, and settlement date, 3) API endpoint GET /settlements for programmatic access, 4) Automated daily email with PDF summary. For accounting reconciliation, the transaction-level CSV is most useful.
Can we get the reports in a format compatible with QuickBooks?

Yes, we have a native QuickBooks integration. Go to Integrations > Accounting > QuickBooks and connect your account. Settlements are automatically imported as journal entries with proper categorization. If you prefer manual import, our CSV export has a 'QuickBooks format' option that maps directly to their import template.
We have a new product launching next month and want to take pre-orders. How do we set this up?

Go to Products > [Product] > Pre-Order Settings. Enable pre-orders and set: estimated shipping date, deposit amount (full price or partial — e.g., 25% deposit), pre-order limit (cap the number), and launch date (when pre-orders start). The product page shows 'Pre-Order' instead of 'Add to Cart' with the shipping estimate. Pre-orders are tagged in your admin for separate fulfillment tracking.
When do we charge the remaining balance for partial deposits?

For partial deposits, you configure a 'Balance Due' trigger: 1) On ship date (charge when the item ships — most common), 2) On a specific date (e.g., 1 week before launch), 3) Manual (you trigger balance collection when ready). We send the customer an email 3 days before the balance charge with a reminder. If the payment fails, they enter a dunning flow with 3 retry attempts before the pre-order is cancelled.
We need a staging environment that mirrors our production setup for testing. How do we request one?

On the Enterprise plan, you get one staging environment included. Go to Admin > Environments > Create Staging. It will clone your production configuration (not data) within about 15 minutes. The staging environment has its own API keys and URL subdomain (staging.yourorg.example.com).
Can we copy a subset of production data to staging for realistic testing?

Yes, use Admin > Environments > Data Seeding. You can select specific data types to copy (orders, products, customers) and apply anonymization rules to PII fields. The seeding job runs overnight and typically completes by morning. Note: payment credentials are never copied — staging uses test payment processors automatically.
We're migrating from Shopify and need to transfer customer data, order history, and product catalog. Do you have a migration tool?

Yes, we have a Shopify migration tool. Go to Admin > Migration > Shopify. You'll need to generate a Shopify API key with read permissions. The tool migrates: customers (with addresses and tags), order history (with line items and fulfillments), products (with variants and images), and collections. Typical migration for your size takes 2-4 hours.
Will customer passwords transfer?

Unfortunately, no — Shopify doesn't export password hashes. Customers will need to reset their passwords on first login. We automatically send a 'Welcome to our new platform' email with a password reset link when the migration completes. You can customize this email template under Admin > Migration > Welcome Email.
A customer accidentally created two accounts with different email addresses. Can we merge them?

Yes, go to Customers > [Customer] > Actions > Merge Account. Enter the other account's email. The merge combines: order history, addresses, loyalty points, store credit, wishlist, and review history. The primary account keeps its email and password. The secondary account's email becomes an alias that also works for login. Merge is irreversible, so we show a preview of what will be combined before you confirm.
What about subscriptions? The customer has an active subscription on each account.

Subscriptions are preserved during merge — both subscriptions transfer to the primary account. If there's a duplicate subscription (same product, same interval), you'll be prompted to choose: keep both, cancel one, or consolidate into one. The customer can manage all their subscriptions from the merged account. Subscription billing continues uninterrupted during the merge process.
We need to enable mandatory two-factor authentication for all users in our organization. How do we set this up?

You can enforce 2FA organization-wide from the Admin Console. Go to Security > Authentication Policies > Require MFA. You'll have options for: TOTP apps (Google Authenticator, Authy), hardware keys (YubiKey), or SMS (least secure, not recommended). I'd suggest giving users a 7-day grace period to set up their 2FA before enforcement kicks in.
We'll go with TOTP. Can we exclude service accounts?

Yes, service accounts can be excluded. Under the same Security > Authentication Policies page, there's an 'Exemptions' section where you can add service account emails. Service accounts should use API keys instead of 2FA. I'll also note that TOTP is an excellent choice — it's the most secure option that doesn't require hardware purchases.
We use Zendesk for customer support. Can we see order information inside Zendesk tickets?

Yes, we have a native Zendesk integration. Go to Integrations > Support > Zendesk. Once connected, Zendesk tickets automatically display: customer's recent orders, order status, tracking info, return history, and lifetime value in a sidebar widget. Your agents can also perform actions (issue refund, update shipping address, create return) directly from Zendesk without switching to our admin.
Can tickets be auto-created from order events?

Yes — go to Integrations > Support > Zendesk > Auto-Create Rules. Common rules: create a ticket when a delivery is 3+ days late, when a refund request is submitted, when a review with 1-2 stars is posted, or when a payment fails. Each auto-created ticket includes full order context and is assigned to the appropriate team based on your Zendesk routing rules.
We want to segment our customers for targeted email campaigns. What segmentation options do you offer?

Our customer segmentation engine supports: 1) Purchase behavior (total spend, order frequency, recency, average order value), 2) Product affinity (categories/brands purchased), 3) Geographic (country, state, city), 4) Engagement (email opens, click rates, site visits), 5) Custom tags you've applied. You can combine conditions with AND/OR logic. Go to Customers > Segments > Create.
Can we use segments as audiences for email campaigns directly?

Yes — segments automatically sync as audiences to our built-in email tool and to connected integrations (Mailchimp, Klaviyo, etc.). Segments update dynamically, so a customer who makes a purchase today will automatically appear in the 'Recent buyers' segment and receive the appropriate campaign. The sync happens every hour for connected integrations.
We need to set up permissions for our new customer service team. They should be able to view and manage orders but not access financial data or settings.

Go to Admin > Staff > Create Staff Account. We have role-based permissions with pre-built roles: 'Customer Service' (view/edit orders, customers, and returns — no financial access), 'Fulfillment' (view orders, manage shipments — no customer PII), 'Marketing' (manage promotions, content, email — no orders), and 'Admin' (full access). You can also create custom roles with granular permissions.
Can we restrict which orders they can see? For example, only orders from their assigned region?

Yes — use our Advanced Permissions with location-based scoping. Under Staff > [Staff Member] > Scope, assign a region or location. They'll only see orders that match their assigned scope. This is great for multi-region teams. You can scope by: fulfillment location, shipping country, order source (web vs. marketplace), or custom tags. Scoped staff can still search globally if they have the order number.
We just launched product reviews and need to set up moderation. We don't want fake or inappropriate reviews published automatically.

Smart approach. Go to Products > Reviews > Moderation Settings. Options: 1) Manual moderation (all reviews held for approval), 2) Auto-approve with filters (reviews are published unless flagged by our AI moderation), 3) Verified buyers only (only customers with confirmed purchases can review). For most businesses, option 2 with 'verified buyers only' gives the best balance of authenticity and volume.
What does the AI moderation flag?

Our AI moderation flags: profanity, personal information (emails, phone numbers), competitor mentions, reviews that don't mention the product (generic spam), duplicate content, and extreme sentiment outliers (could indicate fake reviews). Flagged reviews go to your moderation queue. False positive rate is about 3% — you can override any flag. The system learns from your approvals/rejections over time.
How do I customize our packing slips? We want to include our brand logo and a personalized thank you message.

Go to Settings > Documents > Packing Slip. You can customize: company logo, company info, footer message (great for a thank you note), included fields (order number, items, quantities, special instructions), and QR code linking to your return portal. The editor supports HTML/CSS if you want pixel-perfect control. Preview with a real order before saving.
Can we include a discount code on the packing slip for repeat purchases?

Great retention strategy! In the packing slip editor, add a 'Dynamic Content' block and select 'Unique Discount Code'. The system generates a unique single-use code per order (e.g., THANKS-A1B2C3 for 10% off next order). You configure the discount amount and expiration. This turns every shipment into a marketing touchpoint. Many merchants see a 5-8% redemption rate on packing slip codes.
We want to start offering subscription plans. Does your PaymentGateway support recurring billing?

Yes, we have a full subscription billing module. You can create plans with: monthly/annual/custom intervals, tiered pricing, usage-based billing, free trials, and proration on plan changes. Go to PaymentGateway > Subscriptions > Plans to create your first plan.
How does failed payment retry work for subscriptions?

Our smart retry system uses machine learning to optimize retry timing. Default schedule: retry at 1 day, 3 days, and 7 days after failure. Each retry is timed to maximize approval probability (early morning, beginning of month, etc.). After 3 failures, the subscription enters 'Past Due' status and you can configure dunning emails to remind the customer to update their payment method.
Some of our popular products go out of stock frequently. We want to allow backorders instead of showing 'Out of Stock'. How do we set this up?

Go to Products > [Product] > Inventory and enable 'Allow Backorders'. You can set: 1) Display message when backordered (e.g., 'Ships in 2-3 weeks'), 2) Maximum backorder quantity, 3) Estimated restock date (shown to customer), 4) Auto-disable backorders when restock arrives. Backordered items are flagged in your orders list so your team knows they need special handling.
How do customers know the difference between in-stock and backordered items?

When a product is backordered, the product page shows your custom message (e.g., 'In stock — ships immediately' vs 'Available for backorder — ships in 2-3 weeks'). At checkout, backordered items get a separate line with the expected shipping date. We also send a notification email when the backordered item ships. This transparency keeps customers informed and reduces support tickets.
Customers are dropping off at the cart page. What features can we add to improve conversion?

Key cart page optimizations: 1) Cross-sells — show 'You might also like' below cart items, 2) Free shipping progress bar — 'Add $12 more for free shipping!', 3) Estimated delivery date — reduces anxiety about when items arrive, 4) Save for later — let customers move items from cart without losing them, 5) Trust badges — security seals, return policy badge, payment method icons. Enable all under Settings > Cart > Optimization.
Which of these has the biggest impact?

The free shipping progress bar is the single highest-impact cart optimization. Merchants who implement it see: 15-25% increase in average order value (customers add items to hit the threshold), 5-10% reduction in cart abandonment. The threshold should be set 15-20% above your current AOV. If your AOV is $45, set free shipping at $50-55. This is the sweet spot where customers stretch but don't bounce.

title: Store credit and gift certificate system

parts: We want to issue store credit when processing returns instead of refunding to the original payment method. How do we configure this?

Go to Settings > Returns > Refund Method. You can set the default refund method to 'Store Credit' or let the agent choose per return. Store credit is tied to the customer's account and appears as a payment option at checkout. Credits don't expire by default, but you can set an expiration policy under Settings > Store Credit > Expiration.
Can we issue store credit manually, like for a customer service gesture?

Absolutely. Go to Customers > [Customer] > Store Credit > Issue Credit. Enter the amount and a note (e.g., 'Service recovery for delayed order #1234'). The customer receives an email notification. You can also issue bulk store credit via CSV import — useful for loyalty rewards or compensation campaigns. All credit issuances are logged in the audit trail.
Can we schedule custom reports to be emailed to our team weekly?

Yes! Go to Reports > My Reports, create or open a report, then click the clock icon for 'Schedule'. You can set weekly delivery on any day, choose email recipients (up to 20), and select the format (PDF, CSV, or both). Reports are generated at 6 AM UTC on the scheduled day.
Can we schedule different reports to different groups?

Absolutely. Each report has its own independent schedule and recipient list. You can create report groups by using our distribution lists feature under Admin > Communication > Distribution Lists. Then when scheduling a report, just select the distribution list instead of individual emails.
We need to transfer inventory between our warehouse and retail store. How do we track transfers?

Go to Inventory > Transfers > Create Transfer. Select source and destination locations, add products and quantities. The transfer goes through states: Draft → In Transit → Received. When your team at the destination receives the shipment, they 'Accept' the transfer and inventory counts update at both locations. You can also partial-accept if not everything arrives as expected.
Is there a way to suggest transfers based on stock levels?

Yes — Inventory > Transfers > Smart Suggestions. The system analyzes stock levels vs. sales velocity at each location and suggests transfers to balance stock. For example, if your warehouse has 500 units of a product but your retail store (selling 10/day) only has 20 left, it'll suggest transferring 100 units. You review and approve suggestions, then they become transfer orders. Run suggestions weekly or set up auto-suggestions on a schedule.
We're expanding to French-speaking markets and need to translate our store. Do you support multiple languages?

Yes, we support multi-language storefronts. Go to Settings > Languages > Add Language. For French, we auto-translate: checkout flow, account pages, system emails, and common UI strings. You'll need to provide translations for: product names and descriptions, blog posts, and custom pages. You can upload translations via CSV or use our built-in translation editor.
Can customers switch languages, or is it based on their browser?

Both! By default, we detect the browser language and show the appropriate version. Customers can also switch manually via a language selector in the header. Each language version has its own URL path (yourstore.com/fr/ for French). This is important for SEO — search engines index each language version separately, and you can set hreflang tags automatically.
Can our warehouse team use barcode scanners with your platform for receiving inventory?

Yes! We support barcode scanning through our mobile warehouse app (iOS and Android). Your team can: scan barcodes to receive inventory (updates counts in real-time), scan to pick orders (validates correct items), and scan to ship (auto-captures tracking). The app works with any Bluetooth barcode scanner or uses the phone's camera for scanning.
Do you support generating barcodes for products that don't have them?

Absolutely. Go to Products > Barcodes > Generate. You can create: UPC-A, EAN-13, Code 128, or QR codes. Assign them individually or in bulk. We can also generate and print barcode labels directly — we integrate with DYMO and Zebra label printers. For products without manufacturer barcodes, we recommend using Code 128 format with your own SKU numbering system.
We're running a holiday sale starting December 20th and want a countdown timer on our homepage. How do we add one?

Go to Content > Pages > Homepage > Edit. Add a 'Countdown Timer' block. Configure: end date/time, display format (days:hours:minutes:seconds), colors to match your branding, and what happens when it expires (hide, show 'Sale now live!' message, or redirect to sale page). You can also add countdown timers to product pages under Products > [Product] > Promotional Blocks.
Can we schedule the sale prices to start automatically at the end of the countdown?

Yes! Use Marketing > Sales > Schedule Sale. Set the start and end dates/times for the sale pricing. When the countdown hits zero, sale prices activate automatically — no manual intervention needed. You can also schedule: promotional banners, email campaigns, and social media posts to go live at the same time. The countdown timer, sale pricing, and promotional content all tie together with our scheduling engine.
We're adding a wholesale channel. How do we set up tiered pricing for different customer groups?

Use our Customer Groups feature. Go to Customers > Groups > Create. Create groups like 'Wholesale Tier 1', 'Wholesale Tier 2', etc. For each group, set: percentage discount off retail (e.g., 30% off), minimum order quantities, and specific product access (some products may be wholesale-only). Customers in a group automatically see their pricing when logged in.
Can wholesale customers place orders through the same website or do they need a separate portal?

Both options are available. By default, wholesale customers use the same website but see their discounted pricing when logged in. For a separate experience, you can create a wholesale-only storefront under Settings > Storefronts > Create. This gives wholesale customers their own URL, product catalog, and checkout flow. Most B2B merchants prefer the separate storefront for cleaner branding.
We received our first chargeback and don't know the process to respond. Can you walk me through it?

Don't worry, chargebacks are manageable. When you receive one, it appears in PaymentGateway > Disputes with all the details. You have 14 days to respond. Steps: 1) Review the chargeback reason code, 2) Gather evidence (delivery confirmation, customer communication, signed agreements), 3) Upload evidence through our dispute portal, 4) We submit your response to the card network. You'll get the outcome in 30-45 days.
What evidence is most effective?

The most compelling evidence depends on the reason code. For 'product not received': tracking with delivery confirmation. For 'unauthorized transaction': proof of customer authentication (3D Secure logs, IP match, device fingerprint). For 'product not as described': your terms of service, product descriptions, and any customer acknowledgment. Our dispute portal has templates for each reason code that guide you on what to submit.
Besides abandoned cart emails, what other automated email flows can we set up?

We have pre-built flows for: 1) Welcome series (new account → 3 email onboarding), 2) Post-purchase (thank you → review request → cross-sell), 3) Win-back (inactive customers → escalating incentives), 4) Birthday/anniversary, 5) Browse abandonment (viewed products but didn't add to cart), 6) Replenishment reminders (for consumable products). All under Marketing > Automations > Flows.
Which flows have the highest ROI?

Based on our merchant data: 1) Post-purchase review request — drives social proof at zero discount cost, 2) Win-back series — recovers 5-10% of churned customers, 3) Replenishment reminders — if you sell consumables, this drives 20-30% repeat purchase rate. Abandoned cart is obvious (8-12% recovery). Browse abandonment is underrated — it catches people who were interested but didn't commit. I'd prioritize: abandoned cart → post-purchase → win-back → browse abandonment.

Our ShippingTracker integration is failing with error SHIP-2201. Package tracking updates aren't coming through for orders shipped after December 14th. We have about 200 orders stuck without tracking.

I'm sorry about the tracking disruption. Error SHIP-2201 in ShippingTracker indicates a failure in the carrier API polling service — tracking updates aren't being fetched from the carrier's system. Can you tell me which carriers are affected and your ShippingTracker account ID?
Account CAROL-5510. It's affecting both FedEx and UPS shipments. USPS seems fine. All our FedEx and UPS orders from the past 2 days show 'Tracking Pending'.

Thank you, Carol. I've confirmed the SHIP-2201 error on account CAROL-5510. Our carrier API integration for FedEx and UPS experienced a certificate rotation issue on December 14th that broke the polling connection. USPS uses a different integration path which is why it's unaffected. Our engineering team deployed a certificate update this morning. Tracking data should start flowing again within 4 hours, and backfilled data for the missed period will populate within 24 hours.
Our customers are complaining about not getting shipping notifications. Can we manually trigger notifications once the data backfills?

Yes. Once the backfill completes, go to ShippingTracker > Notifications > Batch Resend. Filter by date range December 14-16 and carrier FedEx/UPS. This will trigger tracking notification emails for all affected shipments. Reference ticket SHIP-2201-CAROL for priority handling.
We want to add a blog to our store for SEO and content marketing. Is there a built-in CMS?

Yes, we have a built-in blog/CMS. Go to Content > Blog > Enable. Features: rich text editor with image embedding, SEO fields per post, categories and tags, scheduled publishing, author profiles, and related products (embed product cards in posts). The blog lives at yourstore.com/blog by default.
Can we use the blog for landing pages too, or is it strictly blog format?

For landing pages, use our Page Builder instead — Content > Pages > Create. The Page Builder has a drag-and-drop editor with sections: hero banners, product grids, testimonials, countdown timers, email capture forms, and custom HTML. Landing pages get their own URLs and aren't tied to the blog chronological format. Most merchants use both: blog for SEO content, Page Builder for campaign landing pages.
ShippingTracker is showing error SHIP-2201 for our account. Package tracking updates stopped coming in for shipments after December 14. We've got 150+ orders with no tracking information.

I understand the urgency. Error SHIP-2201 in ShippingTracker means the carrier API polling service has lost connection and tracking updates aren't being fetched. What's your account ID and which carriers are impacted?
Dave here, account DAVE-8823. FedEx and UPS are both affected. USPS tracking is still working fine though.

Thanks Dave. Looking at account DAVE-8823, I can confirm the SHIP-2201 error. A certificate rotation on December 14th disrupted our FedEx and UPS carrier API connections. USPS uses a separate integration which wasn't impacted. We've deployed a certificate fix and tracking data should resume within 4 hours. Backfill of missed tracking data will be complete within 24 hours.
Customers are asking where their packages are. Is there a way to resend notifications after the backfill?

Absolutely. After the backfill completes, navigate to ShippingTracker > Notifications > Batch Resend. Set the date filter to December 14-17 and select FedEx and UPS carriers. This will resend all tracking notification emails for affected orders. I've created ticket SHIP-2201-DAVE for tracking.
Our checkout page load time is about 4 seconds. That seems slow. What can we do?

4 seconds is indeed slow — checkout should load in under 2 seconds. Common causes and fixes: 1) Too many scripts — check Settings > Checkout > Scripts, remove any unnecessary third-party scripts, 2) Large images — checkout shouldn't have heavy media, 3) Slow payment provider initialization — try lazy-loading payment methods, 4) Geolocation service — if you auto-detect location for tax/shipping, it can add latency. Enable Checkout > Performance > CDN Caching for static assets.
We have 5 third-party scripts on checkout. Which are safe to remove?

Review each script's purpose. Generally keep: payment processor (required), analytics (Google Analytics — lightweight), and fraud prevention. Remove or defer: chat widgets (defer to post-purchase page), retargeting pixels (move to confirmation page instead), and social sharing scripts (not needed at checkout). Moving non-essential scripts to the confirmation page is a good compromise — you still capture the data without slowing checkout.
We're seeing an increase in fraudulent transactions. What fraud prevention tools do you offer?

We have a multi-layered fraud prevention system: 1) Radar — ML-based fraud scoring on every transaction, 2) Custom rules — block by country, amount, velocity, etc., 3) 3D Secure authentication for high-risk transactions, 4) Address Verification (AVS) and CVV checking. All are enabled by default. You can fine-tune sensitivity in PaymentGateway > Fraud Prevention > Rules.
How do we adjust the sensitivity? We're getting some false positives blocking legitimate customers.

Go to Fraud Prevention > Rules > ML Sensitivity. The default threshold is 75 (out of 100). Lowering it reduces false positives but may allow more fraud through. I'd recommend: 1) Review the blocked transactions in the Fraud Review Queue, 2) Mark legitimate transactions as 'approved' to train the model, 3) Add trusted customers to your allowlist. Most merchants find a threshold of 65-70 balances fraud prevention with customer experience.
Our product catalog has grown to 5,000 items and our tagging is inconsistent. How do we clean it up?

Start with Products > Tags > Tag Manager. This shows all tags with product counts. Steps to clean up: 1) Merge similar tags (e.g., 'T-Shirts', 'Tshirts', 't-shirts' → 'T-Shirts'), 2) Delete orphan tags (0 products), 3) Create a tag taxonomy document (standard categories and subcategories), 4) Use bulk editing to apply consistent tags. Our tag suggestion AI can also auto-suggest tags based on product title and description.
Can we prevent inconsistent tagging going forward?

Yes — enable Tag Governance under Products > Tags > Settings. Options: 1) Controlled vocabulary — staff can only select from pre-defined tags (no free-text tagging), 2) Tag approval — new tags require admin approval before being added to the vocabulary, 3) AI tagging — products are auto-tagged on creation based on your taxonomy, with manual override. Most mature catalogs use controlled vocabulary + AI tagging for consistency at scale.
We want to launch a digital gift card program for the holidays. How quickly can we set this up?

You can launch gift cards in about 30 minutes. Go to Products > Gift Cards > Enable. Configure: denominations ($25, $50, $100, custom), design template (we have 5 holiday-themed options), delivery method (email with custom message), and expiration policy (we recommend no expiration for customer goodwill). Gift cards are stored as store credit on the recipient's account.
Can corporate customers buy gift cards in bulk at a discount?

Yes, we support bulk gift card purchases with tiered discounts. Set this up in Products > Gift Cards > Bulk Pricing. Typical tiers: 10-49 cards at 5% off, 50-99 at 10% off, 100+ at 15% off. Corporate buyers get a special checkout flow where they can upload a CSV of recipient emails and personalized messages. Great for corporate gifting programs.
We want to set up tablets in our retail store as product browsing kiosks. Is there a kiosk mode?

Yes, go to Settings > Storefront > Kiosk Mode. This creates a stripped-down browsing experience optimized for touch: larger buttons, no account/login options, simplified navigation, and a persistent 'Scan to buy' QR code. Customers browse products on the tablet and scan the QR to complete purchase on their phone. Kiosk mode auto-resets after 2 minutes of inactivity.
Can customers add items to cart on the kiosk and check out right there?

You can enable full checkout on kiosks, but most merchants prefer the QR handoff for security — it avoids customers entering payment info on shared devices. If you want full checkout, enable it in Kiosk Mode > Allow Checkout and pair the tablet with a card reader (we support Square and Stripe Terminal). The kiosk then functions like a self-service POS.
We need to create 500 unique discount codes for a holiday promotion. Can we do this in bulk?

Yes! Go to Marketing > Discounts > Bulk Create. You can define: prefix (e.g., HOLIDAY), discount type (percentage or fixed), value, usage limit per code (1 for single-use), and total quantity. The system generates random unique suffixes. For 500 codes, it takes about 30 seconds. You can export the generated codes as CSV to distribute them.
Can we track which codes are used and by whom?

Absolutely. Each code's usage is tracked in Marketing > Discounts > Usage Report. You'll see: code, customer email, order ID, discount amount, and date used. You can filter by date range, code prefix, or usage status (used/unused). This is great for measuring campaign effectiveness and ROI.
We want to start an affiliate program. Do you have built-in tools for this?

Yes, go to Marketing > Affiliates > Enable. You can create an affiliate program with: custom commission rates (percentage or fixed per sale), cookie duration (how long referral tracking lasts — 30 days typical), affiliate signup page, unique referral links per affiliate, and automated commission payouts. Affiliates get a dashboard showing clicks, conversions, and earnings.
How do we handle payouts?

Payouts can be: 1) Manual — you review and approve payouts monthly, 2) Automatic — set a minimum threshold ($50 typical) and payment schedule (monthly/bi-weekly). We support PayPal and bank transfer for affiliate payouts. The system generates a 1099-MISC report at year-end for US affiliates earning over $600. All payout history is tracked in Marketing > Affiliates > Payouts.
We're expanding internationally and need to set up shipping zones for EU countries. How do we configure zone-based shipping rates?

Go to Shipping > Zones > Create Zone. You can create zones by individual country or region. For EU, I'd recommend creating two zones: 'EU Tier 1' (Germany, France, Netherlands — higher volume) and 'EU Tier 2' (remaining EU countries). Each zone gets its own rate table with weight-based or price-based tiers.
Can we set different carriers per zone?

Yes, each zone can have its own carrier assignments. Under the zone configuration, go to 'Carrier Rules' and set your preferred carrier per zone. Most of our EU customers use DHL for Tier 1 and a mix of local postal services for Tier 2. You can also set carrier fallback rules in case the primary carrier is unavailable.
We're getting error REF-7703 in PaymentGateway when processing refunds. Batch refunds submitted on December 21st are all stuck in 'Processing' status. About 45 refunds totaling $12,000 are affected.

I'm sorry about the refund delays. Error REF-7703 in PaymentGateway indicates a failure in the refund settlement pipeline — the refund requests were accepted but aren't being transmitted to the payment processors. Can you provide your merchant ID and the batch reference number?
Merchant ID EVE-9901, batch reference BATCH-2025-1221-A. Our customers are expecting their refunds before the holiday.

Thank you, Eve. I've located batch BATCH-2025-1221-A on merchant EVE-9901. The REF-7703 error was triggered by a settlement window timeout — our payment processor's end-of-year batch processing has a narrower settlement window that our system didn't account for. I'm manually resubmitting your batch through our priority settlement channel. The 45 refunds should clear within 6-8 hours.
Is this going to happen again with our December 24th batch?

We've adjusted the settlement window configuration for the holiday period. Your December 24th batch should process normally. I've also flagged your account for priority settlement monitoring through January 2nd. If any issues arise, they'll be caught and resubmitted automatically. Reference ticket REF-7703-EVE for your records.
We're hitting API rate limits during our peak hours. How can we increase our limits?

Your current plan has 500 requests/minute. Options to increase: 1) Upgrade plan (Enterprise gets 2,000/minute), 2) Request a temporary burst increase for known peak periods (Developer > API > Request Burst), 3) Optimize your integration — many merchants reduce calls by 50% with bulk endpoints and webhooks instead of polling. What's your current API usage pattern?
We poll for order updates every 30 seconds during business hours. That's most of our calls.

That's the issue — polling is very API-intensive. Switch to webhooks for order updates: Developer > Webhooks > Subscribe to order.updated. This eliminates all polling calls. You'll receive real-time notifications only when orders actually change, which is dramatically more efficient. Most merchants see 80-90% reduction in API calls after switching from polling to webhooks. This should bring you well under your rate limit.
What self-service options can we give customers to reduce support tickets?

Your customer portal at My Account offers: 1) Order tracking (real-time status), 2) Self-service returns (initiate returns, print labels), 3) Address management (update shipping addresses), 4) Payment method management (add/remove cards), 5) Subscription management (pause, skip, cancel), 6) Communication preferences (email/SMS opt-in/out). Go to Settings > Customer Portal to configure which features are enabled.
How much can this actually reduce support tickets?

Based on our merchant data, a well-configured self-service portal reduces support tickets by 30-50%.
