The biggest impact comes from: order tracking (eliminates 'Where is my order?' tickets — the #1 support request), self-service returns (reduces 'How do I return?' by 80%), and subscription management (reduces 'Cancel my subscription' by 70%). The key is making these features easy to find — add 'Track My Order' as a prominent link in your header and in all transactional emails.
PaymentGateway is throwing error REF-7703 on our refund batch. We submitted refunds on December 22nd and they're all showing 'Processing' with no progress. 38 refunds worth about $9,500 are stuck.

I understand the urgency, especially with the holidays. Error REF-7703 in PaymentGateway means the refund settlement pipeline isn't transmitting refund requests to payment processors. Could you provide your merchant ID and batch reference?
Frank here, merchant ID FRANK-4412, batch BATCH-2025-1222-B. Customers are reaching out asking about their refunds.

Thank you, Frank. I've found batch BATCH-2025-1222-B on merchant FRANK-4412. The REF-7703 error is caused by a settlement window timeout — the payment processor's end-of-year processing uses a narrower window that triggered the error. I'm resubmitting your batch through our priority settlement channel now. Your 38 refunds should clear within 6-8 hours.
Will our next batch of refunds have the same problem?

We've updated the settlement window configuration for the holiday period, so future batches should process without issues. I've also enabled priority settlement monitoring on your account through January 2nd to catch any potential issues automatically. Your ticket reference is REF-7703-FRANK.
We want to A/B test different product page layouts. Do you have built-in testing tools?

We have a basic A/B testing tool for product pages. Go to Products > [Product] > A/B Test. You can test: product image order, description copy, pricing display (with/without 'save X%'), CTA button text, and layout (single column vs. two column). Traffic is split 50/50 by default (adjustable), and results show conversion rate, add-to-cart rate, and revenue per visitor.
How long should we run tests before making a decision?

We recommend a minimum of 1,000 visitors per variant for statistical significance. The A/B testing dashboard shows a 'Confidence' metric — wait until it reaches 95% before declaring a winner. For most product pages, this takes 2-4 weeks. If you have high-traffic pages (10,000+ daily visitors), you can get results in 3-5 days. Avoid making changes during test periods as it invalidates results.
How do I manage SEO meta tags for our product pages? We need to set custom titles and descriptions.

Each product has an SEO section in its edit page: Products > [Product] > SEO. You can set: page title (keep under 60 chars), meta description (under 160 chars), URL slug, and open graph image. For bulk management, go to Products > Export, update the seo_title and seo_description columns in the CSV, and re-import.
Is there an auto-generate option for products without custom meta tags?

Yes! Under Settings > SEO > Auto-Generate, you can set templates. For example: Title template: '{product_name} | {category} | YourStore', Description template: 'Buy {product_name} - {short_description}. Free shipping on orders over $50.' These templates apply to any product without a custom override. This gets you 80% coverage quickly.
We want to enable shopping on Instagram and Facebook. Can your platform sync our product catalog to social media?

Yes, we support Facebook/Instagram Shopping integration. Go to Integrations > Social Commerce > Facebook. Connect your Facebook Business Manager account, and our catalog feed syncs automatically: product images, titles, descriptions, prices, and availability. Products become taggable in Instagram posts and stories. Orders placed through social channels appear in your admin like any other order.
Does it sync inventory in real-time?

Inventory syncs every 15 minutes to Facebook/Instagram. Price and product detail changes sync within 1 hour. If a product goes out of stock, it's automatically marked as unavailable on social channels. For high-velocity products, you can enable 'Priority Sync' which reduces the inventory sync interval to 5 minutes. This prevents overselling on social channels during flash sales.
We've had 5 chargebacks this month, which is more than usual. What can we do to prevent them?

Five in a month is a warning signal — card networks may flag you above 1% chargeback rate. Preventive measures: 1) Use clear billing descriptors (customers should recognize the charge), 2) Send tracking immediately (prevents 'product not received' chargebacks), 3) Enable 3D Secure for transactions over $100, 4) Have a visible and easy return policy (customers return instead of disputing), 5) Set up Verifi and Ethoca alerts — these notify you of disputes before they become chargebacks, giving you 24-48 hours to refund proactively.
What are Verifi and Ethoca alerts?

They're early warning systems from Visa (Verifi) and Mastercard (Ethoca). When a cardholder contacts their bank about a charge, the alert network notifies you BEFORE it becomes an official chargeback. You can then issue a refund proactively, which doesn't count as a chargeback. This keeps your chargeback ratio low. Enable in PaymentGateway > Disputes > Early Warning. The service costs about $40/alert but saves the $25 chargeback fee plus protects your ratio.
We want to add print-on-demand products (custom t-shirts, mugs) to our store. Do you integrate with POD providers?

Yes, we integrate with major POD providers: Printful, Printify, Gooten, and SPOD. Go to Integrations > Print-on-Demand and connect your provider account. Once connected: 1) Design products in the provider's designer tool, 2) They sync to your store automatically as products, 3) Orders are sent to the POD provider for production and fulfillment, 4) Tracking updates flow back to your store. You set the retail price, POD provider charges you the base cost.
What's the typical margin on POD products?

Typical margins: 30-50% for apparel, 40-60% for accessories (mugs, phone cases). For example, a custom t-shirt costs ~$12-15 from the POD provider, and you sell it for $25-30. The tradeoff is lower margins than traditional wholesale, but zero inventory risk and no upfront cost. Start with 5-10 designs, see what sells, then expand winners. Most successful POD merchants eventually transition bestsellers to bulk ordering for higher margins.
Do we have a wishlist feature? Customers are asking for it.

Yes! Wishlists are available but need to be enabled. Go to Settings > Features > Wishlists > Enable. This adds a 'heart' icon to product pages and a 'My Wishlist' section in customer accounts. Customers can create multiple wishlists (e.g., 'Birthday ideas', 'Home decor'), share them via link, and get notifications when wishlist items go on sale.
Can we use wishlist data for marketing?

Absolutely — wishlist data is marketing gold. In Analytics > Customers > Wishlist Report, you can see: most wishlisted products, wishlist conversion rate, and wishlist-to-purchase time. For targeted marketing, create a segment 'Has wishlisted items' and send campaigns like 'Items on your wishlist are now on sale!' or 'Low stock alert for your wishlist'. This typically converts at 3-5x the rate of generic campaigns.
Is there a way to add internal notes to orders? Our fulfillment team needs to communicate about special handling requirements.

Yes! Each order has an 'Internal Notes' section — click on any order and scroll to the Notes tab. Team members can add timestamped comments that are visible only to staff (never to customers). You can also tag team members with @mentions to send them a notification. For special handling, you can add order tags (e.g., 'Fragile', 'Gift Wrap', 'Priority') that appear on packing slips.
Can we make certain tags trigger specific fulfillment actions?

Yes — use Automation Rules under Orders > Automation. For example: 'If tag = Gift Wrap THEN add to Gift Wrap Queue AND print gift message label'. Or: 'If tag = Priority THEN route to Express Fulfillment station'. These rules execute automatically when a tag is applied, either manually or through checkout custom fields. This creates a smooth workflow without manual intervention.
Is there a way to forecast inventory needs? We keep running out of popular items.

Yes, go to Inventory > Forecasting. Our system analyzes historical sales data, seasonality, and trends to predict demand for each product. You'll see: projected stock-out date, recommended reorder quantity, and optimal reorder point. The forecast updates daily and factors in: lead times from your suppliers, current inventory levels, and seasonal patterns.
How accurate are the forecasts?

For products with 6+ months of sales data, forecasts are typically within 15% accuracy. Newer products with less data are less reliable. You can improve accuracy by: entering supplier lead times (Inventory > Suppliers > Lead Times), marking promotional periods in the calendar (Marketing > Calendar), and confirming forecasts monthly. The system learns from variances and improves over time. We also support manual overrides for items where you have insider knowledge (e.g., 'we know a TikTok campaign will spike demand').
We're launching a second brand and want to run it on a separate storefront but manage everything from one admin. Is this possible?

Yes — use our Multi-Store feature. Go to Admin > Stores > Add Store. You can create multiple storefronts, each with its own: domain, branding, product catalog, and pricing. All stores share: customer database, inventory, order management, and analytics. Your admin dashboard lets you switch between stores or view consolidated data across all stores.
Can we share some products between stores but have store-exclusive products too?

Absolutely. When editing a product, go to the 'Store Availability' tab. You can set a product as: available on all stores, specific stores only, or hidden from specific stores. You can also set different prices per store for the same product. Inventory is shared by default, but you can split it (allocate X units to Store A, Y units to Store B) if needed. Most multi-brand merchants share inventory for operational efficiency.
Our transactional emails (order confirmations, shipping notifications) are going to spam for some customers. What can we do?

Email deliverability issues usually come from DNS configuration. Check Settings > Email > Deliverability Audit. Ensure you have: 1) SPF record — authorizes our servers to send on your behalf, 2) DKIM signing — cryptographic verification of email authenticity, 3) DMARC policy — tells receiving servers how to handle unauthorized emails. Our audit tool checks all three and provides the exact DNS records to add.
We have SPF and DKIM set up but still having issues. What else?

Next steps: 1) Check your sending domain reputation at mail-tester.com or Google Postmaster Tools, 2) Ensure you're not on any blacklists (use mxtoolbox.com/blacklists), 3) Review email content — avoid spam trigger words, use a proper text-to-HTML ratio, 4) Use a dedicated sending IP (available on Enterprise plan) instead of shared. Also, enable the 'Warm-up' mode under Email > Sending > IP Warm-up if you recently changed email infrastructure — this gradually increases send volume to build sender reputation.
How does your product recommendation engine work? We want to show 'You might also like' on product pages.

Our recommendation engine uses collaborative filtering (customers who bought X also bought Y) combined with content similarity (products in the same category/attributes). Go to Products > Recommendations > Enable. Widget options: 'Frequently Bought Together' (on product page), 'You Might Like' (on product page), 'Recently Viewed' (site-wide), and 'Personalized Picks' (homepage, based on browse history).
How much data does it need to start giving good recommendations?

The engine needs about 500 orders to start producing meaningful 'frequently bought together' recommendations. For 'content similarity' recommendations, it works immediately using product attributes (category, tags, price range). For new stores, we recommend: start with content-based recommendations immediately, enable collaborative filtering after 500 orders, and supplement with manual curated recommendations for hero products. You can also manually set 'related products' per item under Products > [Product] > Related.
Our annual contract is coming up for renewal next month. What's the process and can we negotiate pricing?

Your contract renewal is managed by your dedicated account manager. They'll reach out 30 days before expiry with a renewal proposal. You can negotiate: pricing tiers, payment terms (monthly vs. annual), and add-on services. Annual commitments typically get a 10-15% discount over monthly billing.
Can we add more user seats as part of the renewal?

Absolutely. Renewal is the best time to add seats since you can lock in volume pricing. Let me connect you with your account manager to discuss the details. They can prepare a custom proposal with the additional seats factored into the pricing.
